answers.answer: Hi Roxanne,#5 in your report suggests one of two things; either you have an area in your heart that is not receiving blood flow (from scar from a prior small heart attack or a severely blocked artery) or it is what we call a "false positive" from attenuation.  Attenuation refers to the imaging modality for the stress test being unable to pick up a signal in that area of concern secondary to breast tissue, the diaphragm being elevated, or fatty tissue.  If you have never had any heart disease, no prior symptoms of a heart attack, and no other cardiac history and you are an obese female, then it is most likely attenuation causing the study to appear that way.  I cannot say with any absolute certainty without seeing your scan myself, but I would suggest you discuss with the cardiologist to see if you need a heart catheterization prior to your next surgery (which is often required for women your age).

question: Thank you for your time and my doctor has suggested that I have an angiogram done.  The following are listed under Test Conclusions and my Dr focused on #5.1)  electrocardiographic portion was without diagnostic changes for new ischemia2) adequate physiologic response to Lexiscan administration3) patient complained of shortness of breath, no chest pain reported4) isolated premature atrial complex, no other arrhythmias5) myocardial perfusion imaging was abnormal.  There is a moderate sized anteroseptal defect of moderate intensity which is primarily fixed with minimal septal reversibility.  Consider attenuation or prior infarction clinical correlation required.6) Overall normal left ventricular systolic function left ventricular ejection fraction of 70% post stress.I'm a 48 yr old female who has gained weight after a laminectomy and obese, although I did not spend my life that way.  : (  I am trying to receive clearance for gastric sleeve surgery and frustrated that I now have to take yet another test.  I do not have diabetes and have never been treated for high blood pressure, although my BP has been higher than normal the past six months.  Other than chronic lower back pain/sciatica and SOB when trying to exercise, I would consider myself to be in good health and want to be in superior health by losing weight asap.  Thank you in advance for your reply, especially to #5.
title: Please interpret my nuclear stress test/ecg results :D
